PM

The Fed is giving the markets the signal it is prepared to wait for a (hopefully) higher build-up in realised inflation and inflation expectations. That has been understood and absorbed by the markets, after so many dovish interactions with Fed Governor Yellen. This underlying ‘understanding’ is manifesting itself via further flattening of the US curve (on a 2v10s basis), as some of the inflation measures inch higher. It is an unstable equilibrium, but it is working for now, as the US economy continues to send worrying signs of deceleration. That could change over the next summer months, as US economic surprise indices try to stage a rebound. For the moment, we remain deeply concerned with the ability of core Central Banks to respond to any potential dip in economic data. Today’s CPI print will be a litmus test for global fixed income.

PM

There's lots more where that came from, but will spare you

11:10 am
PM

There is a strong argument to be made that over the course of the past fourteen years investor interest in emerging markets has (primarily) mirrored USD demand. This is hardly surprising when it is remembered that between the start of 2002 and the summer of 2014 the targeted Fed Funds rate on average lagged behind the headline inflation rate by 64 bp (in sharp contrast to the 294 bp average pick up afforded during the Rubin era of the strong USD). At its most extreme (September 2011) the Fed Funds rate stood 361 bp below the inflation rate, a level only previously seen back in 1975. Little wonder that the FX reserves of China ballooned to USD 4 Trn by the summer of 2014.

This pattern began to play itself out again in late January of this year as it became clear that the FOMC was adopting a more cautious stance as China found itself facing the unappealing prospect of either tightening capital controls (pushing back against its drive towards liberalisation) or continuing to spend USD 100 bn a month in order to prevent a significant devaluation in the CNY. Given that fears of a CNY devaluation had been a cause of major market unrest globally in August of last year (sparking fears of a renewed currency war), this was something to be avoided if possible.

The re-emergence of what looked like the "Fed put" (albeit one in part aimed at relieving pressure on China) was not lost on the market. From late January onwards the USD began to weaken while oil prices recovered and the drain on the value of China's FX reserves was staunched. Investors reacted rationally to this, buying gold, commodity currencies (particularly those with a high yield) and equities.

PM

All this helps explain the remarkable turn-around in markets in the first third of the year. However, there is a potential problem facing the Fed and the U.S. administration as the summer months approach. This is that since mid-April there have been signs of renewed flows back into the USD. This is apparent not only from our own flow data but also from the stalled rally in gold and equities as well as from the mixed price action for the USD against other majors such as the JPY, EUR and GBP. Coming at a time when the CNY is under renewed pressure while the data out of China continues to undershoot expectations, the Fed will undoubtedly be alert to the possibility of another summer of unrest in financial markets. Although never welcome, it could be argued that the bank would be particularly keen to avoid such an outcome ahead of what promises to be a bruising battle for the U.S. presidency in the latter half of the year.

This leaves the FOMC with a difficult balancing act. If they are still aiming for two moves this year then it is reasonable to assume that the second will take place in December (the meeting concludes on the 14th). This then leaves them with moving on June 15, July 27, September 21 or November 2. As the last of these dates comes just days ahead of the presidential election it seems relatively unlikely that they would make a move then. While June 15 is possible it also seems relatively unlikely given the negative shock such a move would create in a market that is completely unprepared for such a move. This therefore leaves just two possibilities, neither of which is particularly attractive. If they hike on July 27 the risk is that they may have to reverse the move should the market prove as fragile as it did in the Augusts of both 2013 and 2015. September is barely better. While it has the advantage of coming after the August danger period, it is also uncomfortably close to the election. Moreover, it is entirely possible that fears of a September rate hike could spark fresh unrest in key markets (most obviously China) anyway.

PM

It is always possible that the Fed will end up going for just one rate hike this year. Indeed, given the potential problems facing markets this summer, this is beginning to look like a distinct possibility. Nevertheless, if the FOMC is to have any flexibility about making a move either in the summer or early autumn then committee members must continue to talk up the possibility of a move.

BE

Let me get some Davy for the summary.

BE

Ahead of its investor event today, Taylor Wimpey has announced enhanced targets for
the group. The current medium-term targets for 2015-17, set out in May 2014, have
been successfully executed and the new targets cover the period from 2016 to 2018. The
three main objectives are:
 An average operating margin of 22% over the period (previous strategy 20%);
 An average return on net operating assets of 30%; and
 £1.3bn in cash returns over the period.
The company has also raised its ordinary dividend. Previously, it had been paying a
‘maintenance’ dividend of c.2%, but it now believes that it can sustain an ordinary
dividend of 5% of net assets. This will be a ‘through the cycle’ dividend and amount to
at least £150m, beginning in 2017.
On top of the £300m special dividend due in 2016, Taylor Wimpey has announced a
further special dividend of £300m to be paid in 2017. In addition to the 5% ordinary
dividend outlined above, this suggests a 2017 pay-out of £450m, ahead of our current
estimate of £400m (a yield of c.7.5% based on last night’s closing price).

BE

UK housing market remains positive
According to the company, the market for new build remains very positive across most of
its geographies, with good accessibility to mortgages driving a healthy environment. It is
still seeing a stable market in central London. Taylor Wimpey is currently 70% forward
sold for 2016 in terms of private sales, and is well positioned for this year and into the
medium term.

BE

While 2016’s dividend is unchanged at £350m,
2017's is increased to £450m (vs. JPMe: £350m). The y/y increase is driven
by a higher ordinary dividend (£150m vs. £50m) reflecting the group's
increased confidence in the long-term sustainability of cash flows. The 3 year
earnings targets have been rolled forward by a year to 2016-18; in the process
margin and ROCE targets have increased. We increase our ‘17/18e PBT
estimates by 4% and 8%, respectively, driving a 14% increase our Price
Target to 250p, implying 35% upside.
 Enhanced dividend policy: The group has announced its intended dividend
payout for 2017. The proposed special dividend is unchanged y/y, in line
with our expectations at £300m. However, the ordinary dividend is
increased by £100m to £150m, taking the overall payout to £450m from
£350m. While there is no specific proposal for 2018, as part of its three year
targets the group has said that it expects to pay £1.3bn in total over the
period 2016-18, implying that ‘18E is likely to see a further y/y increase to
£500m. The increased total payout implies a yield of 7.5% in '17E and 8.2%
by 18E. From ‘17 onwards the group expects to be able to pay out at least
£150m as an ordinary dividend every year, (including through a ‘normal
downturn’), whilst maintaining a high quality balance sheet. The increase
follows a’ comprehensive review process', meaning we assume this £150m
payout has been thoroughly stress tested.

BE

 Increased three year targets: The group is now looking to generate an
average return on net operating assets of 30% between 2016 and '18, and an
average operating margin of c.22%, vs. its previous target of 20% on both
for 2015-17. These are described as ‘stretching long-term targets.’ The
increase reflects 'confidence in the business' and 'a backdrop of strong,
growing housing market'. However, management believes it can meet these
without compromising long-term stability. The statement reiterates that
strategic land and the new Major Developments business continue to provide
scope for ongoing growth without significant additional cyclical risk.

The step up in margin targets is likely to drive consensus upgrades, and in response we raise our price target to 183p. We now see little downside, and upgrade our recommendation from Sell to Hold.

BE

The UK housebuilders have uniformly reported a good start to 2016; buyer
demand remains robust. While the sector has underperformed on concerns
this could change in the coming months, our scenarios suggest that we
need to see dramatic slowdown in order to justify a further sell-off from
here. Furthermore, in all but the most catastrophic of downturns, we
struggle to see dividend estimates coming under pressure. We see this as
an attractive buying opportunity; our assumption that the market is merely
flat leaves us with an average of 25% upside to our price targets.

BE

 We see little risk of a near-term slowdown impacting estimates and
even less risk to dividends: While we see nothing in the current data to
lead us to question our assumption that the housing market is materially
unchanged near term, we are increasingly asked what a bear case for
near term earnings could be. In order to generate double-digit
downgrades in 2017, we estimate we need to see a stalling of house
price inflation and a c.10% decline in sales rates (and a much more
meaningful decline in demand, given that we believe demand for sites
currently outstrips supply). Even under this scenario, we see dividends
as secure, leaving the sector yielding 5-6%. Yield support, coupled with
a current av. P/E of only 8.0x, means we would see little room for derating into downgrades. Our price targets based on a flat market
assumption imply an average of 25% upside, meaning we view the
balance of risk to sector valuations as being materially to the upside.

11:25 am
BE

 While the Central London has slowed, we believe that the perception
of risk exposure to this market is overdone, even for Berkeley Group,
where we remain OW. Increasingly the sector's exposure to London is
focused on affordable outer boroughs that we expect to remain insulated
from the prime slowdown, owing to both a continued undersupply and
additional demand for new build resulting from the newly increased Help
to Buy. While the Prime Central London market gives some cause for
concern, we believe companies’ risk exposure is limited by large, robust
order books and well timed land acquisitions.

PM

Without any great enthusiasm, we upgrade our (absolute) HSBC stock recommendation from Hold to Buy. This reflects (1) the reality of a Q1 2016 outturn which was a little “less bad” than expected, (2) a 9% share price reversal over the past 3 weeks, and (3) perhaps most importantly, our continuing belief that HSBC can and will pay a maintained, albeit uncovered, 51c dividend for 2016e – an implied yield of 8.3%. A Q2 2016 completion of the Brazil disposal would materially underscore this expectation. BUY.

European banks are down 18% YTD, mostly driven by the de-rating…
With 1Q16 results over it is time to take stock. European banks are down 18% YTD
against a market 5% lower, with continuing hair-raising volatility in parts of the banks
index. Our estimates changed surprisingly little during results: interesting considering
the bearishness of many investors we meet. Over the season we cut adj. PBT estimates
for 2016-2018 by 1-2%: we expect this is less than many would suppose.

11:31 am
PM

... with poor sentiment leaving banks the cheapest sector around
Low, flat yield curves, weakening growth and political instability are risks applicable to a
growing list of countries. As regulated, operationally and financially geared entities,
banks should not expect to be immune from such concerns. But modest estimate
revisions and poor stock performances see the Eurobanks P/E relative two standard
deviations below history. On a global basis, banks are cheaper on forward earnings
than all sectors other than Autos & Auto Components (a sector closer to peak than
trough earnings) and yielding more than any other large sector.

PM

At-weight Europe, overweight US, underweight EM: Concentrated top picks list
Despite the relative discount of the sector we maintain a narrow top picks list,
concentrating on banks with excess capital now, high dividend payout policies which
constrain strategic drift, operations in a limited number of countries and an
underweight representation within the earnings mix devoted to market-related
activities. Our top picks are ING, LBG and Swedbank; our least preferred names are
BBVA, Handelsbanken and StanChart.

PM

I will usual place the rest

11:32 am
PM

And a couple of pars from Sandy Chen on the CMA stuff

PM

We had expected/feared that the CMA’s Provisional decision on remedies report on UK retail banking would be a rehash of earlier efforts; it isn’t – it extends the earlier analyses and focusses on what stops customers from switching their current accounts (e.g. lack of trigger moments, lack of confidence in the switching system, worries about transferring overdrafts) and proposes specific remedies that could actually prove effective (maximum monthly charges on overdrafts and other fees, integrated, open banking systems infrastructure).

PM

The bank that stands to be hurt most by these changes is Lloyds (LLOY LN, 67p, £48bn, Sell). Its 25% share of UK personal current accounts is by far the highest; 66% of its operating income comes from net interest income, and the CMA thinks that a substantial portion of this net interest income comes from overdraft charges. The CMA’s proposed remedies are aimed squarely at this; as these come into force in 2017/2018, we expect that LLOY will face particularly strong pressure on its NIMs.

BE

Mark (son of Jim) Slater bought into the IPO here. One moment.

BE

One IPO in which he has partaken this year, buying for both his Growth and his Income funds is Lakehouse. This is a company that carries out functions such as repairs to social housing. Mears is a company that is arguably the best known listed company that performs comparable functions to those of Lakehouse. But Slater noted, ‘the two companies have the same broker, and Mears would have had to agree to that, so they obviously don’t feel that Lakehouse competes with them very much.’

He continued, ‘there were a couple of factors that were important in our decision to buy Lakehouse. The first is that the price came down, the company came to market at an unfortunate time, so had to put the price down, we were able to buy the company at a price to earnings ratio of 8, and at a 30 per cent discount to Mears. The second factor is that Lakehouse has an extremely impressive and experienced management team who know the sector.’

BE

BE

11:41 am
BE

No major surprises in the reported results. However, whilst
trading in three of the divisions is broadly in line, company
specific delivery issues in Regeneration (likely exacerbated by
recent management change) has resulted in a 20% reduction to
FY 2016 PBT. The new Board is undertaking a ‘bottom up’
review of the operations, focusing on Regeneration. However,
until evidence of stability is witnessed by investors, it is hard to
see the underlying value being realised. The H1 dividend implies
a 3.0p FY 2016 dividend, demonstrating the Board’s confidence.
We move to Hold, awaiting further insight to the Board review,
trading stability and a permanent CEO appointment.

BE

Trading details Sales rose 4% to £167.8m (underlying revenues falling 17%),
reflecting the previously flagged challenges in Regeneration and Energy
Services. Group EBITA fell to £5.1m (PHe: £4.6m) resulting in margins of 3.1%
(from 5.5%). Headline PBT of £4.7m (PHe: £4.0m). Within Regeneration
(16% FY 2016 EBITA) contract re-procurement, capital works delays and
budget reductions (rent changes) has resulted in H1 revenues falling 20%.
Furthermore, EBITA (£1.9m from £4.4m) has also been impacted by delivery
and control issues within certain external capital works contracts (£2m H1
impact). These challenges are expected to continue through H2 2016. In Energy
Services (31% of FY 2016 EBITA) these funding delays and a lower carbon
price has also impacted the margin earned on projects (reduced client
contributions to projects). Headline profits fell 12%, but underlying (ex
acquisitions) profits fell to £1.5m from £3.5m. Management has modestly
accelerated investment in smart metering (ahead of potential contract awards),
but we also note contract timing issues within the Warmworks contract.
Compliance (34% EBITA) has performed in line, with with good visibility on
H2 project related works. Recent acquisitions are performing in line.
Construction (19% EBITA) reflects a shift back to an H2 weighting due to
projecting timing with an EBITA contribution of £1.0m.
Net debt and dividend The H1 net debt position was £22.6m, in line. The H1
dividend of 1p implies a full year dividend of 3.0p (2.6x covered).
Outlook. The order book has increased to £636m which provides 90% visibility
over FY 2016. However, the delivery issues in Regeneration and Energy
Services investment drives a 20% reduction in FY 2016 PBT. We now look for
Sep 2016 PBT of £16.0m from £20.0m to give EPS of 7.9p from 9.9p. We make
similar moves to FY 2017 and FY 2018 forecasts. FY2016 net debt forecast
increases to £21.5m (from £17.7m) to reflect the lost contribution (debt still
reduces over our forecast horizon with Net debt/EBIDTA below 1x). Lakehouse
has total facilities of £50m to Dec 2018.
Valuation This is a disappointing development and investors are likely to remain
nervous until the new Board can begin to deliver tangible progress and restore
shareholder value.

BE

Analyst is Andrew Nussey, who gets to accept the corporate client hospital pass.

BE

Blinkx has reported final results for the year to March which are in line with the April trading update. Group revenues were $166.7m, near the mid-point of $165-170m guidance. Within this, Core revenues advanced +12% to $116.0m driven by very robust growth in Programmatic, and now account for 70% of group revenues. Group operating expenses have been reduced by c$40m, equal to 40% of annualised costs. The FY16 EBITDA loss of -$10.5m was consistent with guidance and the group achieved breakeven in Q3, ahead of its expectations. Blinkx guides to a return to full year profitability in FY17 and we raise our EBITDA forecast from -$3.5m to breakeven. Net cash finished the period at $78.5m, equal to 13p per share, and in H2 the group was cash flow positive before acquisition spend. We believe the group made considerable progress in rationalising its product portfolio, investing behind its programmatic platform and reducing opex in 2016, and this positions it well for further recovery in 2017.

BE

Revenues. Blinkx has changed its reporting structure to more accurately reflect its reshaped portfolio. In FY16, the group generated Core revenues of $116.0m, up +12% year on year and now representing 70% of group revenues. Within this, Core Programmatic leapt +68% to $75.2m, while Core Direct fell -30% to $40.9m as customers migrated to the programmatic platform. The group continues to reduce its non-core revenues, which fell -55% to $50.7m in the period. We model stable revenues in 2017 before a return to growth from 2018 onwards. Within this, we expect Core to grow to over 80% of group revenues in 2017.
Operating Expenses. The group has reduced its annualised operating expense base by $40m, equal to 40% of total. We now model a cost base of $64m in 2017.
Profit. We now model EBITDA breakeven for FY17, compared with our previous forecast for a -$3.5m loss. After share options of $4.5m and D&A of $5.0m, we forecast PBT of -$9.5m (was -$12.5m).
Cash. The group was cash flow positive in H2 before a $5m acquisition payment. We forecast modest cash absorption ($4m) in 2017 before the group turns decisively cash positive from 2018 onwards.

Comment on Treatt, the maker of weird stuff, via Investec.

11:58 am
BE

A good 1H result from Treatt. It continues to drive its strategy of focusing on developing longer-term relationships, with larger customers supplying value-added ingredient solutions, and this is paying dividends as margins rise. Profits are 2H weighted so there remains more to be done to deliver forecasts, but there is positive momentum in the business. We make no change to our FY16E PBT forecast and also maintain our TP. We upgrade our recommendation to BUY in light of 10%+ upside in forecast total return.

Interim results from Treatt were ahead of expectations. The group reported PBT of £3.4m vs our forecast of £3.1m, which reflected a 15% increase on 1H15. The difference versus our number was due to lower admin costs. Revenues declined by 1%, but this reflects the changing business mix as the group looks to improve the quality of profits by supplying more value-added ingredient solutions. This mix change was visible in the higher gross margin (23.5% vs 22.1%). Adjusted EPS was 4.72p (+12%) and the interim dividend 1.35p (+5%). Exceptional items (of £218k) reflected some organisational restructuring costs.
As is typical, due to a seasonal stock build ahead of the busier summer season, net debt increased relative to FY15, but against the prior half-year it fell by £1.5m to £8.4m. By year-end, we expect this to fall again to c.£5m, which leaves the balance sheet in good shape ahead of the UK relocation project.
We do not expect to see any cash outlay on the project in FY16E, although the group is in negotiations for a possible site purchase (payment will be conditional on securing planning consent). There is no news yet on the possible settlement of the Earthoil dispute, although a decision is pending. We have included a sum in our FY16E cashflow to cover possible compensation.
We make no changes to FY16E profit forecasts (£8.1m PBT), but increase the tax charge by 250bps to reflect higher levels of US activity (EPS moves to 11.4p from 11.7p). This PBT suggests a slower 2H, but the group had a bumper Q415 which might be difficult to match.
